title.value: “One-Size-Fits-All”? Examining Expectations around What Constitute “Fair” or “Good” NLG System Behaviors
title.justification: The title accurately reflects the main focus of the paper by detailing the exploration of expectations about fairness and appropriateness in NLG system behaviors.
title.quote: “One-Size-Fits-All”? Examining Expectations around What Constitute “Fair” or “Good” NLG System Behaviors

extractions.description: This paper investigates the assumptions and expectations surrounding fairness in Natural Language Generation (NLG) system behaviors. Through five case studies, the authors explore how NLG systems respond to identity-related language features (names, roles, locations, dialect, and style) and examine people's expectations of these system behaviors. The findings reveal tensions between invariance (uniform behavior across social groups) and adaptation (behavioral variation across social groups) and highlight the complexities involved in defining what constitutes “fair” or “good” NLG system behaviors.

type.justification: The paper includes five case studies where the authors empirically examine NLG system behaviors and people's expectations using various identity-related language features.
type.quote: To illuminate tensions around invariance and adaptation, we conduct five case studies, in which we perturb different types of identity-related language features (names, roles, locations, dialect, and style) in NLG system inputs.

name.justification: The paper focuses on Natural Language Generation (NLG) and issues related to fairness in NLG system behaviors, positioning it within the broader field of Natural Language Processing (NLP).
name.quote: Natural language generation (NLG) models are used for many downstream applications involving interpersonal communication, such as text completion, “smart” reply suggestions, and chatbot assistants (Mieczkowski et al., 2021; Trajanovski et al., 2021; Buschek et al., 2021; Liu et al., 2022).

name.justification: The paper extensively discusses fairness, bias, and ethical considerations in AI, particularly in the context of NLG systems.
name.quote: At the same time, there are growing concerns that NLG models and the systems that incorporate them may reproduce or exacerbate biases, causing harms that affect subsets of people (Robertson et al., 2021; Amershi et al., 2019; Hancock et al., 2020; Jakesch et al., 2019; Sheng et al., 2021b).

name.justification: The paper examines user expectations and perceptions, which fall under the domain of Human-Computer Interaction (HCI).
name.quote: Through these cases studies, we examine people’s expectations of system behaviors, and surface potential caveats of these contrasting yet commonly held assumptions.

name.justification: The study uses sociolinguistic theories and methods to investigate language as a social identity performance, connecting it to the field of sociolinguistics.
name.quote: In sociolinguistics, language is a performance of social identity, which extends beyond demographic attributes and includes membership in many types of social groups. We draw on this broad notion of social identity, since it provides a more comprehensive conceptualization of people’s relationships with language.

name.justification: DialoGPT is mentioned as one of the NLG systems used in the study.
name.quote: To observe system behaviors (RQ1), we experiment with three NLG systems that pertain to interpersonal communication: a) chat “smart” reply suggestions using Google’s ML Kit (Kannan et al., 2016), b) email reply suggestions (Deb et al., 2019), and c) dialogue response generation using DialoGPT (Zhang et al., 2020).

is_contributed.justification: The model DialoGPT is not introduced as a novel contribution in this paper; it is used as an existing system for the study.
is_contributed.quote: dialogue response generation using DialoGPT (Zhang et al., 2020)

is_executed.justification: DialoGPT was executed as part of the experiments to observe system behaviors when interacting with identity-related language features.
is_executed.quote: To observe system behaviors (RQ1), we experiment with three NLG systems that pertain to interpersonal communication...and c) dialogue response generation using DialoGPT

is_compared.justification: DialoGPT’s outputs were analyzed and compared to those of other NLG systems in the study.
is_compared.quote: To identify patterns in reply suggestions across the case studies, we use grounded theory methods, including open and axial coding (Charmaz, 2006; Muller, 2014).
